title: Urn, "Tall Green Bloom", 2012
provenance: 2012-2013 Adrian Sassoon, London, new from Designer.
creditline: Museum purchase through gift of Elizabeth and Lee Ainslie and from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund
description: Made by Additive Layer Manufacturing, in a strong green, of upright vase form in neo-classical shape like a tall Wedgwood or Sevres urn, with pierced crossed strands that create both surface and interior patterns
justification:
Michael Eden, an important British studio &nbsp;ceramicist for over twenty years&nbsp; who worked together to create a variety of traditionally fired ceramic forms, predominantly in slip cast earthenware has turned his attention to ceramic-inspired&nbsp; rapid protoyped objects.&nbsp; He was excited by the possibilities the process held for ceramic design outside of the confines of manufacture. At the Royal College of Art, he saw the potential for CAD drawing to achieve works that could not be made by hand and re-define the creative process, first with a piece called “The Wedgwoodn’t Tureen” . 
“The Wedgwoodn’t Tureen”, which draws a correlation between the future of ceramic design and Josiah Wedgwood’s role at a pivotal moment in the first wave of industrialized ceramic manufacturing, is a demonstration of the technology’s circumvention of the material and technical limitations of ceramic. It is in the success of this initial piece that “Tall Green Bloom” proceeds. Eden describes these new works as being the beginning of “a new ceramic language...where the pre-industrial craft meets post-industrial manufacturing.”“Tall Green Bloom”, Created using Additive Manufacturing (3D Printing), is part of a series of iconic ceramic objects from the first industrial revolution with an emphasis placed on the impossibility of their construction through traditional ceramic techniques. The artist intentionally uses complex structures and bright colors that are beyond the possibility of traditional ceramic materials. Eden's use of this technology to achieve these results shows a strong, clear&nbsp;voice speaking to the world&nbsp;in&nbsp;the new ceramic language of his own invention. &nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph: Urn, "Tall Green Bloom", 2012. 3-D printed Nylon. Museum purchase through gift of Elizabeth and Lee Ainslie and from General Acquisitions Endowment Fund. 2013-53-1.
